Award.AwardTitle: Extremal Problems on Graphs Related to Colorings and Cycle Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
A coloring of vertices of a graph G is a partition of the vertex set of G into sets (called color classes) such that the ends of every edge of G are in different classes. The basic coloring problem is to find such a partition with the fewest color classes. Coloring deals with the fundamental problem of partitioning a set of objects into classes that avoid certain conflicts. This model has many applications, for example, in time tabling, scheduling, frequency assignment, and sequencing problems. The theory of graph coloring is among central topics in discrete mathematics. It relates to other important areas of combinatorics, such as Ramsey theory, graph minors, independence number, orientations of graphs, and packing of graphs. Coloring properties of graphs certainly heavily depend on the cycle structure of these graphs. The goal of this project is to study a series of extremal problems related to colorings of graphs and hypergraphs, where answers depend on the cycle structure. The plan is to make significant advances in developing the theory of graph and hypergraph coloring and studying their cycle structure. The project involves a number of graduate students and young researchers.

The main directions of study are planned to be color-critical graphs with small average degree, list coloring, improper colorings, equitable coloring, bounds on the independence number, hypergraph coloring, existence of cycles of specified length in graphs with high chromatic number, Turan-type problems on cycles in graphs and hypergraphs, existence of many disjoint cycles in dense graphs, packing, and list packing. Work in these directions will exploit and possibly develop recent advances in the field including the results of the investigator and collaborators, in particular, graduate students working with him. Among promising tools are the language of potentials and the notion of list packing. Among expected results are enhancements of classical results on disjoint cycles and on the longest cycles in graphs with restrictions on the vertex degrees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The start date  is  July 1, 2016,  the termination date is  June 30, 2021.

Broader impacts: The work of the PI was conducted in active collaboration with   graduate students  Michael Santana, Andrew McConvey, Derrek Yager, Anton Bernshteyn, Ruth Luo, Xujun Liu, Dara Zirlin, Mina Nahvi, Jingwei Xu, Yifan Jing, Grace McCourt, visiting students Fuhong Ma, Pongpat Sittitrai and postdocs Theodore Molla, Mikhail Lavrov, Sean English. It also involved former  graduates Jaehoon Kim, Ilkyoo Choi,  Gexin Yu. For all  graduates this work became an essential part of their  Theses. 
Jaehoon Kim received in the Fall 2019 the Prize of the best young Mathematician in Korea. Anton Bernshteyn graduated in 2018 and has now  tenure track at Georgia Tech. Ruth Luo graduated in 2019 and is now an NSF Postdoc at UC San Diego.
The results of the grant are used in graduate courses in Combinatorics and Graph Theory and discussed at research seminars for the students of the Mathematics Department of the University of Illinois.

Publications: More than 60 scientific papers resulted from the grant, more than 50 of them are already published or accepted by leading refereed journals in the field.

Intellectual merit: As  said in the abstract of the project, the goal of the project was to study a series of extremal problems related to colorings  of graphs and hypergraphs, where answers depend on the cycle structure. The main directions of study were planned to be color-critical graphs with small average degree, list coloring, improper colorings, DP-coloring, equitable coloring, bounds on the independence number, hypergraph coloring, existence of cycles of specified length in graphs with high chromatic number, Turan-type problems on cycles in graphs and hypergraphs, existence of many disjoint cycles in dense graphs, packing and list packing.
The work on the project mainly followed these guidelines, although sometimes interesting related problems were also considered. The most significant results of the project are the following:

1. A stability theorem for Kopylov's strengthening of classical Erdos-Gallai theorems  from 1959 on the number of edges in a graph without long cycles or paths.

2. A well-known theorem of Erdos from 1962  on the number of edges  in n-vertex nonhamiltonian graphs with minimum degree d was refined in several directions and extended to the  subgraph density problem.

3. Refining a theorem of Posa from 1963  on the number of edges  in n-vertex non-l-hamiltonian graphs.

4. Proving a conjecture by Jackson from 1981 on long cycles in 2-connected bipartite graphs  and its extension to 3-connected bigraphs.

5. The notion of superpancyclic hypergraphs was introduced and studied. Reasonably many hypergraphs have this property. A conjecture on necessary and sufficient conditions for this was stated and discussed.

6. The exact bounds on the number of edges in Berge r-graphs not containing a cycle of length at least k were proved for kr+2. A stronger asymptotically sharp bound for 2-connected  Berge r-graphs when k>r+3 was proved.

7. Asymptotically exact bounds on the maximum number of edges in ordered and convex geometric r-graphs with no zigzag or crossing paths of length at least k were proved.

8. All ordered trees and all convex geometric trees with linear extremal function were described. This resolves a problem by Brass-Karolyi-Valtr from 2003 for connected graphs.

9. New results toward Kalai's conjecture on extremal function for tight r-trees were proved.

10. For all fixed s and sufficiently large n all s-tuples (n_1,...,n_s) were  described such that the complete s-partite graph K_{n_1,...,n_s} in every 2-edge-coloring has a monochromatic path with n vertices (and the same problem for a monochromatic n-edge  cycle). In particular, this settles for large n a conjecture by Gyarfas-Ruszinko-Sarkozy-Szemeredi from 2007.

11. Conjectures by Schelp and by Benevides-Luczak-Scott-Skokan-White (for large n) from 2012 on monochromatic paths and cycles in 2-edge-colored graphs with high minimum degree were proved. 
12. DP-colorings were extended to multigraphs, and basic properties were proved.  

13. Extending the strong form of Dirac's Theorem on the number of edges in k-critical graphs to DP-coloring. This settles a question from 2002.

14. Discovering interesting distinctions between DP-coloring and list coloring.  Answering related question of Grytczuk on planar bipartite graphs.

15. DP-coloring of hypergraphs, fractional DP-coloring and online DP-coloring  introduced and studied.

16. Exact bounds on the number of edges in multigraphs (and for some simple graphs) critical with respect to improper DP-colorings with two colors.

17. The question whether the packing chromatic number of cubic graphs is bounded was answered in the negative, and the  similar question  for subdivisions of cubic graphs is bounded in the positive.

18. A series of results on reconstructions of graph properties from the set of induced (n-l)-vertex subgraphs of an n-vertex graph.

19. A strengthening of a theorem of Dirac and Erdos from 1963.
20. Proof of a conjecture of Holzman on the sizes of 1-cross-intersecting set-pair systems.
